articles.headline: For Euro Nations, There Are Strings Attached
articles.snippet: Few economists predict the euro zone will splinter, but many more see some breakup risk. However, for strong and weak members, a return to national currencies would be painful.
articles.abstract: Few economists predict the euro zone will splinter, but many more see some breakup risk. However, for strong and weak members, a return to national currencies would be painful.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT  Even as British officials and other Europeans bear down on a resolution to Ireland’s debt crisis, there is a lingering unease in the markets about whether one or more countries might eventually bolt the currency union.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and James Kanter

articles.headline: Google TV, Usability Not Included
articles.snippet: Google wants to put the Web on your TV set. But two new devices from Sony and Logitech that offer to be the intermediaries are so complex they may alienate non-technophiles.
articles.abstract: Google wants to put the Web on your TV set. But two new devices from Sony and Logitech that offer to be the intermediaries are so complex they may alienate non-technophiles.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google Mail. Google Phone. Google Voice. Google News.

articles.headline: China’s Censors Misfire in Abuse-of-Power Case
articles.snippet: The heavy-handed efforts to control the story of a fatal accident involving a police official’s son have been met with scorn.
articles.abstract: The heavy-handed efforts to control the story of a fatal accident involving a police official’s son have been met with scorn.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAODING, China  One night in late October, a college student named Chen Xiaofeng was in-line skating with a friend on the grounds of Hebei University in central China. They were gliding past the campus grocery when a Volkswagen sedan raced down a narrow lane and struck them head-on.

articles.headline: Justices Are Long on Words but Short on Guidance
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court led by Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. has been criticized for the quality of its judicial craftsmanship.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court led by Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. has been criticized for the quality of its judicial craftsmanship.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In June, the Supreme Court issued a decision on the privacy rights of a police officer whose sexually explicit text messages had been reviewed by his employer. Ever since, lower court judges have struggled to figure out what the decision means.

articles.headline: Chrysler Falls Behind as G.M. and Ford Recover
articles.snippet: As G.M. prepares to go public and investors bid up Ford’s stock, Chrysler is being cast as the odd man out in Detroit’s resurgence.
articles.abstract: As G.M. prepares to go public and investors bid up Ford’s stock, Chrysler is being cast as the odd man out in Detroit’s resurgence.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The Big Three is starting to look more like the Big Two, as Chrysler drifts further behind its larger hometown rivals Ford and General Motors, whose newly issued stock will be publicly traded for the first time on Thursday.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: U.S. Taxpayers Recover Billions in Sale of G.M. Stock
articles.snippet: Taxpayer ownership of General Motors was halved after the nation’s largest initial stock offering ever.
articles.abstract: Taxpayer ownership of General Motors was halved after the nation’s largest initial stock offering ever.
articles.lead_paragraph: American taxpayers’ ownership of General Motors was halved on Wednesday, and billions of dollars in bailout money was returned to the federal government, as a result one of the nation’s largest initial stock offerings ever.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: Wall Street, the Home of the Vanishing I.P.O.
articles.snippet: Despite the initial public offering by General Motors, that tactic for raising capital is not the corporate rite of passage for start-ups that it once was.
articles.abstract: Despite the initial public offering by General Motors, that tactic for raising capital is not the corporate rite of passage for start-ups that it once was.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the golden oldies of the stock market tables  GM  is back. But where did all those other stock symbols go?

articles.headline: Foreclosure Fix Is Seen as Distant
articles.snippet: Since all 50 states signed on to a investigation of big mortgage lenders, a public tug of war has ensued.
articles.abstract: Since all 50 states signed on to a investigation of big mortgage lenders, a public tug of war has ensued.
articles.lead_paragraph: Changing the face of foreclosure in America will take some time, several state attorneys general said Wednesday, cautioning that an agreement with major lenders over revamped foreclosure practices was not imminent.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: Fewer Fall Delinquent in Paying Mortgages
articles.snippet: The Mortgage Bankers Association reported the lowest delinquency rate since the beginning of 2009, lowered by loan modifications to some and evictions of others.
articles.abstract: The Mortgage Bankers Association reported the lowest delinquency rate since the beginning of 2009, lowered by loan modifications to some and evictions of others.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as the fight over foreclosures continues, the high tide of delinquency among homeowners has begun to recede.
